comments.commentBody:
Amazing.

Amazing athlete, amazing person, amazing tennis player.

She earns and she deserves every win that she gets.

Bravo, Kim, Bravo.

That had to be one of the worst efforts of Federer's career as a top player.  How do you go from serving as well as he did against Soderling, in horrific conditions, to serving so poorly, in perfect conditions?  And his timing was off all day.  He never once got into a rhythm, and Im assuming it was his inability to move his feet.  Honestly, he shouldnt have won a single set.  Probably a good thing he lost, cause if he played like that against Nadal tomorrow, it would have been a romp.
Ask for Brian!

I feel like there are some oddities about the US Open that might have influenced the dullness of the women's final. There's just no way any match could live up to the thrilling semifinal between Federer and Djokovic, and it's my opinion that both of those women knew that. It's not excuse for Zvonereva, but she obviously wilted in that setting, that huge stadium. They both could have played there hearts out and it still wouldn't have measured up. That's simply not fair to women's tennis, because it sets them up to fail no matter what.

I can hear the criticism already, so let me buttress my argument. I've been watching tennis for a long time, and it seems to me that the real contests in the Slams are the semifinals. Very often they're the most competitive and alive matches of the tournaments. You hear the t.v. commentators say as much. My opinion since nobody asked or ever will, play the women's final before the men's semis.

And the prize money announcement was hugely embarrassing for Clijsters - you could see it all over her face when Mary Carillo practically yelled it out. It was tacky to an extreme and Clijsters' face just registered this horrified look. Anyway, I'm a big fan of both of those women. Congrats to both for a great tournament - they earned their spots in the final.
Kim vs. Venus was much better tennis.

As the great Jimmy Durante so eloquently put it, "What a perdicamint!"  Without question, the Mets must resign themselves to ridding their clubhouse of Perez and Castillo  (money be darned)!  If no one will take them- and why would anyone do so except even up for a personnel headache of equal proportion and salary?- it makes no sense to keep two guys on the roster who will never even be used.  Hopefully, K-Rod will either remain on the DL for the length of his contract or attract the attention of another team (he's not the lights-out closer that management had thought they were signing but he's better than some and his salary shouldn't be too prohibitive).  Beltran will probably have to stick around for another season but he'll be playing for his next contract and could manage to put up some decent numbers.  The Mets will surely need a starting second baseman (it's clear that Tejada isn't the answer).  And, hopefully, they can convince Takahashi to re-sign or they'll need a closer AND a set-up man.  Plus a fourth outfielder and a starting pitcher- or two (depending upon the state of Santana's shoulder).  And a new manager.  And a GENERAL manager.  And, if they accomplish all of that, they may even have a .500 ballclub.  When do tickets go one sale...?
My father, a department chair at our local university, once told me, "a Bachelor's degree proves only that you can sit still for long periods of time."

Looking at the edits of Wikipedia article is mental masturbation.  It conveys no new knowledge about the content and is no use academically.  Just another technologist trying to be in the humanities....

Interesting that Wikipedia's practice of recording & retaining all edits echoes Ted Nelson's original concept of hypertext.  And how amazing it is that our capacity to store data digitally allows us to go this far toward the realization of a concept that was totally impractical when first suggested in 1963.

ARMs position as CPU architecture of choice for mobile appears unassailable.
Even Intel, with Infineon acquisition has acknowledged as much.

Looking forward to those 2.5GHz Eagle powered phones in 2012.
Coupled with LTE/Wifi (or even Wifi 2.0) ...things get even more interesting in the high end.

Such power coupled with broadband wireless access will enable new usage models and new fortunes in the mobile value chain.

-Tek
https://twitter.com/TektonikShift

I don't think that anyone is "publishing" these books. It is being used as a singular example of how accurate and deep the Wiki records are. And so, from this point, Wikipedia should be praised at how well in keeps digital records.

However, does this make Wikipedia any better than another encyclopedia? In a world of microwave dinners and Big-Gulp 64oz Tigermart express drinks, and the McDonald's fast espresso to go line, we hardly take the time to do independent, quality, critical research for ourselves. How are people going to take the time to read the edits and background information?

After all, in the end, it's still the governing board that determines which content is suitable for face/cover value, and so Wiki is not any different from another. Who funds this governing board? Does the board, just like our presidents, accept lobbying bribes from varying viewpoints when performing their duties? We do not know. If X Company has a major stake in Wikipedia through legitimate investments are through sizable "donations," do you think the editors in chief would all be of free conscience in order to publish accurate content about a story that might damage X Company? They would probably alter it, soften it, or censor it altogether.

The only way to get accurate information is to get it yourself. And this is hardly ever done, so the information that enters our mind is what others want us to believe, and so we are destined to be influenced wrongly by those with super-wealth and power. We think that we think; therefore, we are not.
AND he missed the fly...

Larry in post No. 6 says it well: This article glosses over the big negative lurking in the background: allowing users to 'customize' their newsreading experience will only exacerbate the tendency for people to live in an echo chamber of their own design.....and........I don't think it's a coincidence that the state of the country has declined so precipitously, in tandem with daily newspaper readership.

Eggsactly, Larry, and fellow readers here. The decline of our daily snailpapers, aka read print newspapers, means a more and more divided nation, with no end in sight, except eventual political and social decline and global ceding of the superpower status to China. It's in the cards. The death of Mr Paper means the death of civial society. Larry words need to be heeded. I am heeding them in my igloo in Nome!

Funny yes. Humor helps here. But believe you me, snailpapers are going the way of the dodo bird, sooner or later, and it won't be funny then. The loss of print newspapers and the migration of news to screens, aka blogs, means that our nation has become irretrievably divided, which is why from my igloo here in Nome, I cry for thee, America. Without print newspapers making up the agenda of our once great nation, the center is lost and that is why the power is shifting over to Japan and China, where good sense still remains part of civil discourse, or else. Yes, cute idea, fly swattering. But in the end, the loss of Mr Paper signals the loss of our once great Republic.
Brilliant, simply brilliant. Would that all newspaper advertising could be so good and so effective at putting a message across. Score one for the guys in Melville.
Cute ad.  But it won't save the print media.
Yes. And how many iPads does it take to wrap a fish ?... Nevertheless, the thing is obviously not bad. Very, very practical when you think of it.

These companies need to hire more women in order to come up with practical applications. I want to design a robotic house painter. It would be an XY axis on a frame attached to a paint sprayer. It would have a camera. First it would survey the area to be painted. A person would choose the paint colors for the trip, siding, and architectural details. A person would attach the sprayer hoses and heads for the colors. Then away it would go, adjusting itself to paint very precisely so masking would not be needed. High winds, rain, or other situations would shut it down.

How about a gardening robot that could check soils, leaves, fruit, tag for pruning (not sure you want your bot to "run with pruning shears"), assist with planting and repotting.

Get off the idea of making these machines look like humans -- lots of money is wasted on some guy's fantasy of building an ultimate lover. That's why you need women doing these designs; we mainly want our machines to just do heavy lifting and NOT want anything in return.

While this is interesting, it is worth noting the obvious: Wikipedia is unusual in the way the text is created. Other texts emerge from multiple input, but not in the same sense. To track the interaction of ideas between two scholars, one studies their communication - in their letters, for example, or the public debate in journals and conferences. This is something scholars have been doing for a long time and not an innovation of the Internet. Within documents, scholars have long compared different drafts. It is possible that information technology will make this easier, but equally possible that old files will be deleted and tracked changes "accepted" into oblivion.

In general, Wikipedia is good for the more technical and less controversial subjects, as experts will often put a lot of time into improving a page. Controversial topics are targets for those on one or other side. A big controversy like the Iraq War will at least be carefully monitored to keep this under control. The worst pages tend to be those on controversial topics where interest is lower, as here partisan points can remain in place for long periods.

The process of Wikipedia's creation, while certainly interesting as a study of debate, does not have quite as much significance as Mr Bridle seems to be claiming.

And Fran, (#1), from the same quote, shouldn't it be "ensure"? At least here in the USA, insure means insurance (life, auto, etc) and ensure is used convey "make sure."
As to your point about IBM's 2 products, are they that much of a competitor to Sybase such that SAP would consider them to be enemies? My background is with DEC VAX/Alphas/Integrity running OpenVMS so I am not familiar with IBM's software products?
Terrible ad from Apple's POV.  "Look how easy our iPad breaks".

Education is the race between civilization and catastrophe.
--Arnold Toynbee
Education teaches one to think rationally and critically, and to question authority.  It's the opposite of indoctrination, which fosters blind obedience and devotion.

naive take. first of all it is a elite opinion maker/politician driven prejudice not redneck bigotry. Reason is geopolitical conflicts like Israel-Palestinian. Far right has also found a way to get mainstream legitimacy, first time since world war 2, riding on related issue.  Even this column is in a way promoting prejudice by referring to "Muslims" as a single entity. In contract "Christians" are usually not referred like that. One Example is "... that Muslims haven’t said nearly enough about those Muslims who kill other Muslims".  So every Muslim should be concern with action of other billion Muslim.

Mr. Kristof, how can you believe that a mosque built near ground zero will not be celebrated as a triumph of the 9/11 hijackers?   While I absolutely do not condone anti-Islamic speech or the ridiculous burning of Korans, I believe that those who wish to build a mosque at ground zero do not truly have interfaith understanding in mind.  Please don't pretend that the huge crowds of Muslins in the middle east did not cleebrate in the streets on September 11, 2001.   And although I, as many Americans, wanted to believe in 2001 that the hijackers were part of a marginalized group, that does not now appear to be the case.  Imams who were declared as moderate back then, have proved to be otherwise (e.g. Anwar Al-Awlaki).  I have a great deal of respect for your opinions, and I am usually energized by your columns.  But as much as I respect the rights of all to religious freedom, I still believe that the proposal to build a mosque near ground zero is at its core a monument to a bloody victory.
